questions.question: What is the basic deduction calculation for the qualified business income deduction?
Which of the following statements is true regarding taxpayers with taxable income below the taxable income limitations for the qualified business income (QBI) deduction?
options: QBI deduction is only allowed if the taxpayer is a qualified trade or business (QTB).
A qualified trade or business (QTB) and specified trade or business (SSTB) are treated the same.
QBI deduction is limited to 50 percent of W-2 wages.
QBI deduction is a phased-out deduction if a specified service trade or business (SSTB).

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a specified service trade or business (SSTB) for purposes of the qualified business income deduction?

An individual taxpayer received a Schedule K-1, Partner's Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc. from a small partnership, in which the taxpayer owns a 50 percent interest. The qualified business income amount attributable to the taxpayer is $70,000. That is the taxpayer's only qualified business income, and the taxpayer has no capital gains or other investments. Ignoring the W-2 wage and property limitation, what is the net amount of increase to taxable income from the partnership income?

Jason is a limited partner in a partnership, and his filing status is single. In Year 1, Jason received a K-1 from the partnership with the following amounts of allocated partnership income and loss: $15,000 ordinary business income, $4,000 interest income, $5,000 in guaranteed payments, and $7,000 of long-term capital gain. The partnership is not a specified service trade or business, and Jason’s taxable income before the QBI deduction is $150,000.

What is Jason’s qualified business income (QBI) for purposes of calculating his qualified business income deduction?

Sam has the following items of income for Year 1: Salary of $75,000, ordinary business income from a partnership in which Sam is a limited partner of $15,000, guaranteed payment from the partnership of $5,000, and interest income of $2,000.

What is Sam’s QBI for Year 1?
Which of the following is the overall limitation to the qualified business income (QBI) deduction?
options: Taxable income limitations based on filing status
Lesser of: 50 percent of W-2 wages or 25 percent of W-2 wages plus 2.5 percent of the unadjusted basis of qualified property
Lesser of: the combined QBI deductions or 20 percent of the taxpayer's taxable income in excess of net capital gain
Lesser of: 50 percent of the combined QBI deductions or 20 percent of the taxpayer's taxable income in excess of net capital gain

questions.question:
Calculate the taxpayer's qualified business income deduction for a qualified trade or business:[BOX] * Filing status: Single

 * Taxable income: $100,000

 * Net capital gains: $0

 * Qualified business income (QBI): $30,000

 * W-2 wages: $10,000[/BOX]

David is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $100,000. He is also the sole owner of an S corporation, whose principal activity is providing tax consulting services to clients. This year, the S corporation’s qualified business income was $50,000. The S corporation paid $10,000 in wages to a part-time employee, and its unadjusted basis in qualified property was $40,000. David does not itemize deductions for the current taxable year.

What is David’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction?

David is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $100,000. He is also a limited partner in a partnership. The partnership allocated David $25,000 of ordinary business income this year. The partnership earned this ordinary business income from its principal activity of performing consulting work for clients. David’s share of the partnership’s W-2 wages is $6,000, and his share of the qualified property is $3,500.

What is David’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction, assuming he has no other sources of income this year?

Tim is a single taxpayer with $150,000 of taxable income before the Section 199A QBI deduction in Year 1. The entirety of his earnings comes from an S corporation that he solely owns and that operates a qualified trade or business. As part of determining his taxable income for the year, Tim determines that his S corporation earned $170,000 of net taxable income. Tim reports this on Schedule C of his individual income tax return. What is Tim’s QBI deduction for Year 1?

An individual taxpayer with a filing status of married filing jointly owns an interest in a partnership that provides commercial cleaning services. For the current year, the taxpayer's joint taxable income, prior to deducting any qualified business income, is $300,000. The taxpayer's Schedule K-1, Partner's Share of Income, Deductions, Credits, etc., and additional details from the partnership provide the following information:[BOX] * Ordinary business income (loss) -------------------------------------- 	 $250,000

 * Employer's Form W-2 wages deducted

  in determining ordinary business income -------------------------------- 	 $75,000

 * Unadjusted basis of partnership assets used

  in the partnership's business ----------------------------------------- 	 $100,000[/BOX]

What is the taxpayer's qualified business income deduction for the year?

David is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $100,000. He is also a limited partner in a partnership. The partnership allocated David $25,000 of ordinary business income this year. The partnership earned this ordinary business income from a qualified trade or business. David’s share of the partnership’s W-2 wages is $6,000, and his share of the qualified property is $3,500.

What is David’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction, assuming he has no other sources of income this year?

Calculate the taxpayer's qualified business income deduction for a specified service trade or business:[BOX] * Filing status: Single

 * Taxable income: $300,000

 * Net capital gains: $0

 * Qualified business income (QBI): $50,000

 * W-2 wages: $10,000[/BOX]

Sarah is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $300,000. She is the sole owner of an S corporation that is not a specified service trade or business. This year, the S corporation’s qualified business income was $50,000. The S corporation paid $10,000 in wages to a part-time employee, and its unadjusted basis in qualified property was $40,000. Sarah will take the standard deduction this year and does not have any other adjustments for the current taxable year.

What is Sarah’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction?

David is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $300,000. He is also a limited partner in a partnership. The partnership allocated David $25,000 of ordinary business income this year. The partnership earned this ordinary business income from a qualified trade or business. David’s share of the partnership’s W-2 wages is $6,000, and his share of the qualified property is $3,500. David will claim the standard deduction this taxable year, and his taxable income before the QBI deduction is $310,000.

What is David’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction, assuming he has no other sources of income this year?

Alex is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $300,000. She is also a limited partner in a partnership, whose principal activity is providing tax consulting services to clients. This year, Alex’s allocation of the partnership’s QBI is $50,000. The partnership paid $10,000 of wages to a part-time employee, and its unadjusted basis in qualified property was $40,000. Alex will take the standard deduction this taxable year and has no other adjustments.

What is Alex’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction?

David is an individual taxpayer who earns a salary of $300,000. He is also a limited partner in a partnership. The partnership allocated David $25,000 of ordinary business income this year. The partnership earned this ordinary business income from its principal activity of performing consulting work for clients. David’s share of the partnership’s W-2 wages is $6,000, and his share of the qualified property is $3,500. David will claim the standard deduction this taxable year, and his taxable income before the QBI deduction is $310,000.

What is David’s qualified business income (QBI) deduction, assuming he has no other sources of income this year?
